Revenue_CPaaS.description: CPaaS revenue driven by SMS/RCS/Voice messaging volume, carrier relationships, and pricing dynamics. Commoditized market with intense competition. Management de-emphasizing; planned for divestiture in 2026.

Revenue_SaaS.description: SaaS revenue (Zenvia Customer Cloud + legacy products) driven by net customer adds, average revenue per user expansion, churn rate, and franchise channel scaling. Primary growth engine post-CPaaS divestiture.

Revenue_Total.description: Consolidated revenue. Critical inflection point: divestiture of CPaaS (72% of FY2025 revenue) creates step-down in total revenue but shifts mix to higher-margin SaaS.

Gross_Margin_CPaaS.description: CPaaS gross margin highly sensitive to carrier cost inflation and competitive pricing. Collapsed from 24% to 12% in one year. Management expects recovery to 20% by Q4 2025 but structural pressure likely persists.

Gross_Margin_SaaS.description: SaaS gross margin driven by AWS/GCP infrastructure costs (~15-20% of revenue), customer support/success costs (~10-15%), and mix shift toward higher-margin Zenvia Customer Cloud (target 70% GM) vs legacy SaaS products (~50% GM).

Gross_Profit.description: Consolidated gross profit. Key insight: mix shift from CPaaS (12% GM) to SaaS (60%+ GM) dramatically improves gross profit dollars, but only if SaaS revenue scales sufficiently to offset CPaaS loss.

OpEx_G&A_Fixed.description: Fixed general & administrative expenses representing absolute floor for public company operations. Includes corporate overhead (legal, finance, HR, IT), public company costs (audit, IR, compliance), and minimum staffing for LATAM footprint. Floor: BRL 30-35M annually regardless of revenue scale.

OpEx_G&A_Variable.description: Variable G&A expenses that scale with revenue and operational complexity above the fixed floor. Includes incremental finance/legal/HR headcount as company grows, expanded compliance requirements, and regional administrative costs. Scales at 3-4% of revenue above BRL 500M threshold.

OpEx_G&A.description: Total general & administrative expenses. H1 2025: BRL 48M (8.3% of revenue, down from 14.5%). Management targeting 7% of revenue but constrained by fixed floor. Operating leverage emerges only at revenue > BRL 500M.

OpEx_R&D.description: Research & development expenses. H1 2025: BRL 20M (3.5% of revenue). SaaS-centric model requires sustained R&D to maintain competitive AI/CX features. Expected to increase as % of revenue post-CPaaS divestiture (SaaS more R&D-intensive). Floor: BRL 35M minimum to maintain competitive feature parity and platform stability.

S&M_Direct_Sales.description: Sales & marketing expenses for direct sales channel (enterprise and mid-market). Higher CAC burden (12-15% of direct channel revenue) due to field sales teams, enterprise sales cycles, and account management. Scales with direct channel revenue contribution.

S&M_Franchise.description: Sales & marketing expenses for franchise channel. Franchisees bear local CAC; Zenvia pays franchise royalty (~20-30% of franchise revenue vs 100% internal CAC for direct). Lower S&M ratio (2-3% of franchise channel revenue) for franchise support, training, and brand development. Scales with franchise channel revenue contribution.

OpEx_Sales_Marketing.description: Total sales & marketing expenses. H1 2025: BRL 54M (9.3% of revenue). Franchise model scaling designed to reduce consolidated S&M burden. Expected to decline to 7.0% as franchise channel reaches 50% of new bookings by Year 3.

EBITDA.description: Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization. Normalized LTM June 2025: BRL 100M (8.6% margin). Key metric for debt service coverage and valuation. Target: 25-28% margins post-transformation (capped by Economic Governor constraints).

D&A.description: Depreciation and amortization. H1 2025: BRL 43M annualized (~BRL 86M annually). Primarily intangible amortization from M&A (~BRL 60-70M). Declines over time as intangibles fully amortize.

NOPAT.description: Net operating profit after tax. Current state: ~BRL 10M (EBITDA BRL 100M - D&A BRL 86M = BRL 14M EBIT, less ~BRL 4M tax provision = BRL 10M). Used for ROIC calculation.

WC_Receivables.description: Trade receivables driven by days sales outstanding. Current: 65 days blended (CPaaS longer cycle, SaaS faster). Post-CPaaS divestiture: DSO improves to 55 days (SaaS contracts with advance billing). Scales with revenue at DSO/365 ratio.

WC_Payables.description: Trade payables driven by days payables outstanding. Current: 73 days (inflated by carrier payables for CPaaS volume). Post-CPaaS divestiture: DPO declines to 45 days (standard supplier terms without carrier dependency). Creates WC cash outflow in divestiture year.

WC_Prepayments.description: Deferred revenue from SaaS prepayments (customers pay upfront for annual/multi-year subscriptions). Creates negative working capital benefit. Scales with SaaS revenue at ~10-15% of annual SaaS revenue. Partially offsets receivables WC requirement.

Working_Capital.description: Net working capital requirement. Current: BRL -239M (negative due to high carrier payables). Post-CPaaS divestiture, WC structure changes dramatically: (1) receivables decline (lower revenue), (2) payables decline sharply (no carrier costs), (3) prepayments increase (SaaS growth). Net effect: positive WC ~2% of revenue.

CapEx.description: Capital expenditures. H1 2025: BRL 18M (~3% of revenue). CPaaS: low CapEx (mostly IT infrastructure). SaaS: higher CapEx (product development, cloud servers). Expected to increase as % of revenue post-divestiture (4.5% of SaaS-dominated revenue).

Invested_Capital.equation: Working_Capital + Intangible_Assets + PP&E (or equivalently: Equity + Debt + Earnouts - Excess_Cash)
Invested_Capital.description: Economic capital deployed in business. Current: BRL 1,056M (77% intangibles from M&A). Post-divestiture: declines by ~BRL 170M (CPaaS IC removed), partially offset by SaaS growth (~BRL 50-100M added over 3 years). Critical for ROIC calculation.

ROIC.description: Return on invested capital. Current: 1.0% (deeply sub-WACC). Target: 10-12% by 2028. Requires both NOPAT expansion (SaaS scaling, margin improvement) and IC optimization (divestiture). Key value driver.

Free_Cash_Flow.description: Unlevered free cash flow. Current: Negative (H1 2025 OCF BRL -18M). Post-divestiture: EBITDA BRL 70-80M - CapEx BRL 25M - WC BRL 0-10M = FCF BRL 45-65M (before debt service). Critical for debt paydown and equity valuation.

Debt_Service_Interest.description: Interest expense on debt. Current: 15-17% on BRL 93M = BRL 14-16M annually. Post-divestiture debt paydown: declines to BRL 0 (assume full elimination of interest-bearing debt with proceeds). Interest rate risk mitigated by debt reduction strategy.

Debt_Service_Principal.description: Principal amortization and acquisition earnout payments. Current: BRL 100M+ annually (disclosed 'BRL 114.8M outlay next 12 months' for debt + earnouts). Post-divestiture: declines to BRL 20-25M (residual earnout installments only after 75% debt paydown). Timing risk: Dec 2026 maturity creates execution deadline.

Debt_Service.description: Total required cash outflow for debt obligations. Current: BRL 115M annually. Post-divestiture: declines to BRL 20-25M (earnout installments only). Reduction of BRL 90M annually improves FCF available for growth investment.

Net_Debt.description: Net debt trajectory. Current: BRL 60M (debt BRL 93M - cash BRL 33M). Target: Reduce to BRL 0-50M post-CPaaS divestiture (75% of proceeds to debt paydown). Key metric for credit risk and equity valuation (EV - Net Debt = Equity Value).

Equity_Value.description: Intrinsic equity value per DCF. Current market cap: BRL 370M ($67M). Valuation hinges on: (1) probability of CPaaS divestiture success, (2) SaaS scaling trajectory, (3) margin expansion realization, (4) discount rate compression as risk declines.

coverage_manifest.description: Verification that all critical financial components are represented in the DAG and linked to valuation. REFINE has expanded decomposition to 29 nodes (15 exogenous) from T1's 22 nodes (8 exogenous).

revenue_components.rationale: Revenue decomposed by business segment (CPaaS vs SaaS) to model mix shift from divestiture. Total revenue is derived sum. No further product-level split (Customer Cloud vs Legacy SaaS) due to insufficient Y0 calibration data.

margin_components.rationale: Margins modeled separately by segment due to vastly different economics (CPaaS 12% vs SaaS 60%+). Critical for projecting consolidated GP post-mix shift.

operating_expense_components.rationale: REFINE expanded OpEx to capture: (1) G&A fixed floor vs variable scaling, (2) S&M channel economics (direct vs franchise). R&D remains single node with floor constraint. Covers >95% of OpEx with improved granularity for operating leverage modeling.

profitability_components.rationale: Standard profitability cascade. EBITDA = GP - OpEx. NOPAT = (EBITDA - D&A) × (1 - Tax). Used for ROIC and FCF calculations.

capital_components.rationale: REFINE expanded WC to three components (receivables, payables, prepayments) to model CPaaS divestiture balance sheet restructuring. CapEx remains single node (revenue-mix-weighted). IC and ROIC unchanged. Critical for transformation thesis capital efficiency.

cash_flow_components.rationale: REFINE expanded Debt_Service to separate interest vs principal/earnouts to model divestiture proceeds allocation. FCF = NOPAT + D&A - ΔWC - CapEx (unlevered). Net_Debt dynamics model financing side. FCF after debt service determines equity cash generation.

valuation_linkage.rationale: Terminal node. Equity_Value = f(FCF projections, discount rate, Net Debt). All upstream drivers feed into this valuation output.

strategic_discontinuities_covered.cpaas_divestiture: Modeled as step-function reduction in Revenue_CPaaS (to zero in Year 2) with offsetting cash inflow (divestiture proceeds) and debt reduction.
strategic_discontinuities_covered.saas_scaling: Modeled as elevated Revenue_SaaS growth (25% → 12% CAGR fade) with margin expansion (GM: 57% → 65%) and operating leverage (EBITDA margin: 9% → 28% capped by Economic Governor).
strategic_discontinuities_covered.debt_deleveraging: Modeled via Debt_Service_Interest and Debt_Service_Principal dynamics. Divestiture proceeds reduce both components, lowering future total debt service from BRL 115M to BRL 20-25M and improving FCF.
strategic_discontinuities_covered.franchise_channel_scaling: Modeled via S&M_Franchise node capturing lower CAC economics (2-3% vs 12-15% for direct). As franchise channel grows from 15% to 50% of new bookings, consolidated S&M ratio declines from 9.3% to 7.0%.
strategic_discontinuities_covered.working_capital_restructuring: Modeled via WC_Receivables/Payables/Prepayments to capture CPaaS divestiture impact: (1) DSO improves 65→55 days, (2) DPO declines 73→45 days (removes carrier payables), (3) SaaS prepayments increase. Net WC shifts from -20% to +2% of revenue.

missing_components_and_justification.interest_expense: Not explicitly modeled as separate node; embedded in Debt_Service_Interest. Interest expense becomes immaterial post-deleveraging (BRL 0M after debt paydown vs current BRL 14-16M).
missing_components_and_justification.tax_loss_carryforwards: Not explicitly modeled. DTA of BRL 85M exists but realization timing uncertain. Conservative approach: assume cash taxes = (EBIT × 25%) once profitable. NOL shield modeled in GIM Tax_Rate driver (0% Years 1-2, ramping to 25%).
missing_components_and_justification.acquisition_earnout_conversion: Not explicitly modeled in DAG. Treated as financing event: if BRL 100M earnout converts to equity, reduces Debt_Service_Principal but dilutes FDSO. Modeled in equity bridge (A.2) and Debt_Service_Principal driver narrative.
missing_components_and_justification.fx_translation: Not modeled. All projections in BRL (reporting currency). FX risk captured in discount rate (EM premium 2.5%). Avoids complexity of forecasting USD/BRL while preserving risk adjustment.
missing_components_and_justification.revenue_product_mix: Revenue_SaaS not split into Customer Cloud vs Legacy due to insufficient Y0 product-level data. Product mix impact on gross margin modeled via Gross_Margin_SaaS driver evolution (57% → 65% as Customer Cloud becomes dominant). Adequate for base case; would require refinement for product-level scenario analysis.
